bibl.title: Letter from Carlos O. Coello to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1923

div1.p: Coello discusses the sailing routes between South America and Australia, Southeast Asia, Europe and the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos O. Coello to Henry Rose Carter, May 20, 1923
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Guayaquil May 20, 1923
Dr. H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General.
U.S. Public health Service
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
As soon as I received your letter of last month,
I started to get from the right sources, the information that you want, and
in consequence I wrote to the Captain of the port of Guayaquil, to the Consuls
of Ecuador in Lima and Valparaiso and to the Consul of Perú in Guayaquil.
None of them have answered me yet, but I can tell you that I know
already what their answer will be, and my idea in doing so was just to
get the data in an official way.

Between Ecuador and Australia or the ports of S.E. Asia
there is not navigation. Until before the war occassinal sailing vessels
used to come from Melbourne, etc loaded with coal; very seldom they were
steamers, but always east bound, never from Ecuador to Australia or near
by regions. To the Chilian Coast, I have been informed, tramp steamers run
at present in the same way, they bring coal to the Northern part of Chile, but
they return via Panamá Canal and Europe, while the Japanese Steamers, more
or less regular, that Call at Callao, go back to Asia and Australia by San Fran-
cisco; never directly. From the only port of importance in the Colombian Coast (Buena-
Ventura), there is no service of ocean transportation with the zone in which we are interested.
As soon as I get the answers I expect, will be sent original to you, and I will write
you again anyway, on the subject.
Glad to have the opportunity to do something for you, I am Doctor,
